conclusion: The bullet travels horizontally just before impact.
The ping-pong ball + plasticine (mass M) is initially at rest.
The bullet (mass m) lodges in the ball – the collision is perfectly inelastic.
During the very short collision external forces (weight, table reaction) do not change the horizontal momentum, so horizontal momentum is conserved.

After the collision the “lumped body’’ (ball + bullet) leaves the table edge with no further horizontal forces; gravity acts only vertically, so the horizontal velocity remains constant during the fall.
Horizontal momentum before = horizontal momentum after, m v = (M + m) V.
The time of flight t is derived from vertical displacement: h = ½ g t²  ⇒  t = √(2h/g).
During the time t, the lumped body travels a horizontal distance s, so s = V t ⇒ V = s/t.
Insert t from the previous step: V = s / √(2h/g) = s √(g / 2h).
Solve the momentum equation for v and substitute V: v = (M + m) V / m = (M + m)/m · s √(g / 2h).
The muzzle (exit) speed of the bullet is v = (M + m) s √( g / (2h) ) / m.
All quantities on the right (M, m, s, h) are directly measured; g ≈ 9.81 m s⁻².
